text: back in the driver's seat Toronto's
Mayor Rob Ford seen leaving the
greenstone addiction facility just
outside the city
after two months of treatment he spoke
to reporters in what was at times a very
emotional confessional I underwent
hundreds of hours of intensive therapy I
now know I now know that the staff at
green stone saved my life this video
where he seen shouting and using abusive
language and appears to be drunk was
just one of the many embarrassing
episodes which brought the mayor of
Canada's most populous city to global
attention rob ford also admitted smoking
crack cocaine his sometimes rowdy
behavior attracted a lot of criticism
not least from his colleagues at City
Hall he called for him to resign he
didn't but now admits he was in denial
about his addiction and says he's sorry
I look back on some of the things I have
said and some of the things I did when I
was using I am ashamed embarrassed
and humiliated I was wrong and I have no
one but no one to blame but myself the
mayor says he'll continue to receive
ongoing treatment but hopes that the
personal won't get in the way of the
political he's running for a second term
as mayor in elections this October his
opponents say he's failed the city with
his policies and needs to move on for
Rob Ford the top priority is rebuilding
trust after a difficult and very
dramatic year rajini Varden arden BBC
News Washington
